properties.name: 3DSokobanTest
properties.description:
Sokoban is a puzzle video game where the player pushes boxes around, trying to get them to specific locations. The game was designed in 1981 by Hiroyuki Imabayashi, and first published in December 1982.

The original example shows a how to push multiple objects in a row, and how to check if the player has won.

This 3D version also shows 3D camera controls, switching perspectives, and tweening.

objects.name: TutorialText
objects.string:
Change Camera: Tab
Walk Forward: W
Restart Game: R

events.comment: Toggle boolean that decides which camera controls to use
Setting variables to prepare camera tween
First person camera controls, using the secondary pointer object for a zoomed out camera,
Keeping the camera angle within 0-360 degrees and changing the camera based on the Camera object position
Rotating based on the angle of the point object, to prevent a 360 degree camera spin to get to 0 degrees
Setting variables that are used for the direction of movement, if keys or buttons are pressed.

If one of those direction variables are changed, create a marker object on the player.
Then, using a "while" event type, check if the marker object is on a an object from the group named "objects".
When the marker has finished moving, check to see if it's in collision with a wall or not. And then if a box ends the turn on top of a Goal object.
Reset direction variables to 0 to prevent the above events from triggering again without the player pressing a key.
Change the scene to the current scene to reset the level.
If all goal objects have their animation changed to "filled", show the WinGame layer.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: PANDAKO-GitHub
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MousePointerLock
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
description: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
For example, a user can rotate or continue to manipulate an object by moving the mouse endlessly ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://mouse-pointer-lock)).
Without the pointer lock, the rotation or operation will stop the moment the pointer reaches the edge of the browser or screen.
Game players don't have to worry about leaving the gameplay area or accidentally clicking on another application that moves the mouse focus away from the game.
Locking the pointer locks `MouseX()` and `MouseY()` expressions.

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the X-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementX

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the Y-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementY

eventsFunctions.description: Lock the mouse pointer to hide it.
eventsFunctions.name: RequestPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Unlocks the mouse pointer and show it.
eventsFunctions.name: ExitPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the mouse pointer is locked.
eventsFunctions.name: isPointerLocked
